Parking tickets should not lead to poverty.
support Senate Bill 1786

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

Each year in Illinois, more than 50,000 people have their driver's licenses suspended for unpaid parking tickets and other reasons unrelated to their driving records or public safety. These license suspensions lead to people losing their jobs. Not being able to get to work means they cannot pay the fine, trapping people in a vicious cycle of debt, poverty and even incarceration.

This week, your State Representative will have a chance to vote to end this practice in Illinois. Tell your Representative to support Senate Bill 1786 — the License to Work Act. The measure is set to be heard in Committee this Wednesday, May 1.

Overdue parking tickets and other non-moving violations shouldn’t send entire families into poverty. Governments can hold people accountable without taking away their ability to make a living. Illinois’ current policy forces people to choose between unemployment and the risk of going to jail for driving on a suspended license.

The License to Work Act is a bipartisan bill that will eliminate driver’s license suspensions as a penalty for unpaid tickets and most other non-moving violations. It is crucial that our representatives in Springfield pass this legislation as soon as possible.

Tell your Representative to support Senate Bill 1786 — the License to Work Act before Wednesday’s hearing.

Thanks for sticking with us,

Ben Ruddell
Director of Criminal Justice Policy, ACLU of Illinois
